div1.head: Newspaper clipping, Washington Post, September 1, 1901 and autographed note by Jefferson Randolph Kean.
div1.opener:
Wash. Post Sept 1, 1901
(note gen Kean's comment on back)
div1.p:
The mosquito-yellow-fever tangle gets
worse and worse. Our army surgeons at
Havana, after proving to their own satis-
faction that an infected mosquito can
communicate yellow fever to a human be-
ing--achieving a death rate of 40 or 50 per
cent. by way of riveting the argument--
have now run up against Dr. Caldas, the
Brazillian expert, who has a serum. They
agreed to give Caldas a trial. The latter
pumped his serum into a man, then the
Gorgas mosquitoes bit him, and now the
man is dead. Upon this showing Chief
Surgeon Havard refuses to play with
Caldas any more, declares that his serum
is worthless, if not “inimical to health.”
and ordains that, for the future, his mos-
quitoes will do the killing without any
foreign assistance. On the other hand.
Caldas pooh-poohs Havard; insists that
the mosquitoes cause blood-poisoning, not
yellow fever, and in a general way inti-
mates that our army surgeons don't know
yellow fever from tetanus. And there
they are--all by the ears and the very
devil to pay. It's a ten to one shot that
Caldas knows more about it in a minute
than Gorgas & Co. will know in twenty
years, but that proves nothing. If the
War Department is bent on experiment-
ing further, why doesn't the Secretary
employ some yellow-fever experts, such
as Dr. Joseph Holt, or Dr. Matas, or Dr.
Saloman, of New Orleans, or Dr. Brun-
ner, of Savannah, or fifty others I might
name? What's the use of spending all
this money and killing a lot of innocent
people unless the men in charge of the
enterprise know enough to utilize the re-
sults? HA!HA!!!.. 1901 (over)
